document.title: Doctrinal Elements of a Curriculum Framework for the Development of Catechetical Materials for Young People of High School Age

BE8CDE3B82A94CCB95209BA2DE3A98DF.description:
Occasional joint statements on matters of
doctrine and belief (e.g., joint statement with
Anglicans on Mary, joint statement with
Lutherans on justification).

31F3915259984DF0AA3EF6706A0FDA61.description:
A willingness to meet face to face for prayer
and dialogue.

E7D30782271B47688935C8954E0AEAF1.description:
Since Vatican II, the Catholic Church has initiated
and sponsored many meetings and dialogues
with hope for movement toward unity. Positive
outcomes include the following:

DA09C59E507B4BCF8BCB5D7E93D55549.description:
In each case, some degree of politics also
contributed to the fractures.

56BC1F26B4224343AE4DBC9D85B1F795.description:
In each case, there were disagreements
about doctrine.

87315700A5F946D5A478EBB7330C46EB.description: There were various reasons for the divisions.

6E3604321C6C441E87AD748369E32D55.description:
What caused the four divisions in Christianity from the
time of Ephesus, Chalcedon, the Schism of 1054, and
the Protestant Reformation? Is there any hope of unity?

27FAD3125175458E864426D9534BD650.description:
Sometimes, however, we overemphasize some
aspects of the truth at the expense of other aspects.
Serious, respectful, and loving pursuit of the whole
truth can help us recapture the needed balance.

42D2DC83164A49DD81DEDCA15782E126.description:
Where there are intrinsic contradictions in belief,
one belief is true and one must be false.

8D264FD869C240929C97FA97334D9067.description:
While unity of Christians is an important goal, the
Catholic Church cannot compromise on the truth
of what God has revealed. Truth is one; we need to
subject ourselves to the whole truth.

ED15D209327B419C8073B590BD0CBC5F.description:
If unity of people in faith is the real goal, why can’t
each side compromise?

1B7D5B9DF057446682D6B7BF64FDC3FC.description:
Catholics are to be respectful of people in their
intrinsic dignity but not tolerant of falsehood.

F13D3A45AFDE4C15A46681641F306B2A.description:
Respect involves the effort of mutual respect and
charity, and a refusal to treat one as less worthy
because of differences.

DB421397E4424E9295FCE3DE361DBBF2.description:
Judgment about the truth of the Catholic faith does
not mean that Catholics should not show respect
toward people of other faiths and religions.

8E9E3E1FD8A94636893D040C6FB44C61.description:
Isn’t it more important to show tolerance and not say
that the Catholic faith is better than any other?

EFBF81B7783749578AB4E3BFF6B54F21.description:
The Church engages in many types of dialogue,
both ecumenical and interfaith. Those dialogues
are characterized by respect and aim to bring about
more unity.

EB46664F28F64A99AF2F98085754CD4D.description:
If one has been given the gift of faith and chooses
to reject or neglect that gift, that person acts in a
way that is gravely wrong.

13843CE0CE054586ADBDA9F45FE3440D.description:
No, that statement is not true. The fullness
of Revelation and truth subsists in the Catholic
Church.

576095892CE94D61AAAE1CF16FCD46D5.description: Isn’t one faith or religion just as good as any other?

2CFC9F94C1164CACA38D86852F015391.description:
Can and should involve working together in
service to those in need.

1688D51D5F864C73B68AD47BEB6F5785.description:
Requires training in accurate knowledge of
other religions.

9DCF08615F3041018D033240BA180F66.description:
Requires respect and understanding of differences
in culture as well as in belief.

948DA17F02894080A06E5FFF4A9876E7.description:
Such dialogue requires mutual search for truth
among those learned in their own religious
traditions.

B767F9122CBA453C8CBE7D7287AFBF1F.description: The dialogue of shared spiritual experience.

041CE7C575304673AFD33F2637BEC1E7.description: The dialogue of theologians and scholars.

4B7DE694BC2547799AD077C8D762424A.description: The dialogue of shared service to the needy.

5D47052837D24434BE11E8DB098A413F.description:
The dialogue of daily life in religiously
pluralistic societies/communities.

3C70A335227C4DF19C9FCC22F1BB7E47.description: There are many forms of interreligious dialogue.

93BA41E15B40401799765411F8693E9C.description:
“‘Although in ways known to himself God can
lead those who, through no fault of their own,
are ignorant of the Gospel, to that faith without
which it is impossible to please him, the Church
still has the obligation and also the sacred right
to evangelize all men’” (CCC, no. 848; LG, no.
16) and thereby bring all to Jesus Christ and to his
Church (Rom 11:12, 15, 25; CCC, nos. 674, 1043).

A754BF18C41A4EE5A32D06661F1ED20A.description:
“Those who, through no fault of their own, do
not know the Gospel of Christ or his Church, but
who nevertheless seek God with a sincere heart,
and, moved by grace, try in their actions to do
his will as they know it through the dictates of
their conscience—those too may achieve eternal
salvation” (CCC, no. 847; LG, no. 16).

29F6BF96004C41CAAB3470368041F61B.description:
Sanctification is for human beings to
participate in the love of God now and
eternally.

8D3670EAE9FD4BCE9E9E54BCAF1E0AA7.description:
Salvation is a gift of grace available through
faith in Jesus Christ.

1680F484A7D34B5F93DD2C70C10138B6.description: Jesus Christ as the Son of God.

823E94E52EB5493A9CA8181F7CD450F0.description: God is one and that God is Triune.

C4F0A7D4F8AA4D528A8DED08CFF4A128.description:
“All salvation comes from Christ the Head through
the Church which is his Body” (CCC, no. 846).

61958278A4C948409D2CE506EFEE6B7C.description:
The Catholic Church possesses the fullness of the
means of salvation willed by God as the ordinary way of
saving all people.

0FE35AD7CB6E4D738888D9203AE17B86.description:
Sanctification is for human beings to
participate in the love of God now and
eternally.

8B44F86FC94644B0B94D7606B9690278.description:
Salvation is a gift of grace available through
faith in Jesus Christ.

6849C13A7F254D26AFB5EEA240B18B14.description: Jesus Christ as the Son of God.

15344E55E5F945DCB9898F85DFBDEBE5.description: God is one, and that God is Triune.

029019B4A21242AEA5843347D1B62B27.description:
The fulfillment of the values and virtues of
other religions is found in what the Catholic
Church proclaims:

FDB888BDA65C49EFBFB6FB6D825CA532.description:
Those who do not know Christ but who still strive
to know and live in truth and holiness can be
saved.

0C258A851F5342C4B08AA154E6DBF76D.description:
These religions contain elements of truth and
virtue, which can help orient their members
toward reception of the Gospel.

96D474A10A9446C1B9F812787BEC7821.description:
Many of these religions teach to some degree
compassionate action, moral restraint, spiritual
discipline, and respect for human dignity.

1834A21F26EC4E3F99CA598923BCD201.description:
As human beings we share a common origin
and end.

69E53B84F93C4219BB4BEC517BBF5A01.description:
There are non-Christian religions common in the
United States, including major world religions such
as Hinduism and Buddhism, and others such as Sikhs,
Mormons, and Bahai.

6C56809718824179A1C4C18E685F529D.description:
The Catholic Church seeks to engage the Muslim
community in dialogue to advance human
solidarity.

D84ED1E2DCEF468DAB31F807847D92B2.description: The Crusades and their lasting impact.

3CC6A35376E34B7CAB7484E1DB244E15.description:
Unlike the Catholic Church, Islam has no central
figure of authority on matters of faith and morals;
there are also different ways to interpret the
Qur’an.

EA19F0610FEE482988D6236B8AA39FDD.description:
Islam has no sacramental economy; Islamic
law requires testimony of faith, prayer, fasting,
almsgiving, and pilgrimage as expressions of faith.

79117E00845143EF9A6DBEC0F23808CE.description:
There are many common elements of moral life and
practice between Catholics and Muslims.

568580469BE74AE5AB00D0B7CC19318F.description:
The Muslim people do not acknowledge God as the
Father of Jesus, or Jesus Christ as the Divine Son of
God, nor do they accept the Triune God, but they
do revere Jesus as a prophet and Mary as the Virgin
Mother of Jesus.

B961C69244F54B29A28706E7B144E460.description:
The Catholic Church and Muslims acknowledge
God as the Creator and claim ties to the faith
of Abraham.

FF0849CC2F504505BA92FC2380F5D709.description:
Monotheistic (but non-Trinitarian) faith in
common with Jews and Christians.

3445F1A70EBD4EE19884108990E0CF39.description:
Deepen mutual understanding of the one God
and his plan for the world.

B63757275FC44D168B9B5F9A65F8EE05.description:
Give common witness on matters of peace
and justice.

DDC5EDB1921F48A38EB9719C1C800E9B.description:
Grow in mutual respect for one another as sons
and daughters of God.

49E1C17EC8BD48EDAE9FEC1962D7C921.description:
This dialogue also has an interfaith character
because of the differences in faith and in
sacramental understanding and practice.

FBCD5341196B45FFA41710405FBF08EC.description:
This dialogue has a unique character in that we
share roots of faith.

2AF0E21D5B874458BC56BB1E617210C8.description:
In the twentieth century, the Catholic Church
dropped from its liturgy any inference that the
Jewish people as a whole were responsible for the
Death of Christ because the truth is that the sins of
all humanity were the cause of his Death.

5A5863EF9B3840A99E20C93477632C23.description:
The Catholic Church condemns all unjust
discrimination, including anti-Semitism.

46F818F5A8EE4ADEB88403EACA07A6E9.description:
Anti-Judaism or anti-Semitism was evident among
Catholics for many centuries.

A96217D8C79142D19D3E69FBDAB39291.description:
The Jewish people continue to rely on the ritual
prescriptions of the first Covenant reinterpreted for
post-Temple Judaism.

03ED6C1B2E8348749BA7D76323F3DCA4.description:
The Jewish people do not acknowledge Jesus as a
Divine Person, the Son of God, or the promised
Messiah, nor do they accept the revealed truth
of the Triune God, which is what is unique to
Christian Revelation.

DADBE91E9F2947229B7576F7A5E8BB61.description: Fundamental differences with the Catholic Church.

709113B08A1D476C9D2690F66B19BA4A.description:
Jesus Christ drew on the Decalogue and the
teaching of the prophets in his teaching on
self-giving love and moral living.

E8DB1A1E6E1143989730D4B9CDDD9C1A.description:
The Decalogue is a strong part of Catholic
moral teaching and tradition.

2FBD500CA1F444B785CB9D5F60B21A57.description:
Catholics and Jews share common elements of
moral life and practice:

4E7223A1A798428393DDC165D226EFDD.description:
The New Covenant with Jesus Christ is the
fulfillment of the promises of the first Covenant
between God and the Jewish people.

925C9AE058FF4B6CBA8ABCEACD75F21A.description:
Our Savior, Jesus Christ, was born and raised as a
Jew. Mary, the Apostles, and the disciples were
also Jews.

2DCC423204BE481B9154562EFCE53256.description:
The Jewish people are the original Chosen People
of God; Christians are the new People of God
(CCC, no. 840).

9F54F058C00A42CFBF0AC6C51BB62226.description:
The patriarchs of the Jewish people—Abraham,
Isaac, Jacob, and Moses—are also the ancestors in
faith for members of the Catholic Church.

B24EF19680394D36B7D4124CCC85A74D.description:
Unlike other non-Christian religions, the Jewish
faith is a response to God’s Revelation in the Old
Covenant (CCC, no. 839).

E706BC8BEF224C64938874960FE711F1.description:
The relationship between the Catholic Church and the
Jewish people holds a unique and special position

38A7EA1D7A884A61A59F32DB8A396C5A.description:
The Jewish people were God’s special choice to be
the instrument for the salvation of the world. They
were the first to hear the Word of God, that is,
Divine Revelation (CCC, no. 839).

1374CAD8B22D43F1BBFE6AF8549C70EF.description:
Pope John Paul II referred to the Jewish people as
“our elder brothers.”

FE6B25C1ED714971B761DF45EFC163EE.description:
The link between the Catholic Church and the Jewish
people is special.

A21F39BEEE604CD6903897FFFB50F8A2.description:
The Relationship of the Catholic Church to
the Jewish People

B36D17509EEC425B84D6592C054EF5F1.description:
Greater obstacles continue to arise in doctrine
and in praxis: e.g., ecclesial communions allowing
women and non-celibate homosexuals to serve as
ordained ministers.

89F45DF04C24436A85F826C9AC177813.description:
A shared understanding of interpreting
revealed truth (Scripture read through the lens
of Tradition), e.g., such a starting point exists
with the Orthodox Churches.

64440633CC4249D3ACE25F524EEBAC29.description:
A visible continuity with the ancient Church
(Apostolic Succession).

3FA1150353164DB09EDC7491498A1733.description:
Greater hope of restoring full communion where
there is

9BE0929445BE49A3A3746F4319B2969E.description: Collaboration in activities of service to others.

A66E58DC968B47ECB836424A9C22F512.description:
Dialogue among theologians of different
churches and communities.

A458F96060B747F7829C0C61DD3B78E6.description:
Ecumenical formation of clergy and laity
(knowledge of sacred theology including a
historical perspective; understanding of the
problems and benefits of the ecumenical
movement).

50038B7EF1E14FEEB84DFEF620C537DC.description: Conversion of heart by all the faithful.

83542E1F19344BB791AAED26F7AF61E5.description:
Renewal of the Catholic Church in fidelity to
her vocation.

02F6DCC76D734A849686804D74BB6D67.description:
Ecumenical activity requires the following (CCC,
no. 821):

825578BD3E1D4C5DAE4CD3252E6AC37A.description:
Ecumenism involves efforts aimed at fostering unity
between the Catholic Church and other churches
and Christian ecclesial communities.

EBF48F9FB54D4110B3C315C17318D163.description:
Many of these bodies (e.g., Baptists,
Congregationalists) view the church as a local
congregation and not a worldwide communion.

A76BA9E361F941B6B616DE00509C57F5.description:
Differences in doctrine, sacramental
understanding and practice, morality.

5B11181E4DC5448A8DF50BBB2FE443B4.description:
Shared belief in Christ and the Triune God but
a strong emphasis on sola Scriptura (Scripture
alone) as the standard for determining belief.

0C3F4D2F0F974F40A3E692C212AB95A5.description:
Some are the result of further divisions
among ecclesial communions which separated
from the Catholic Church, e.g., Methodists
separated from the Anglican Church.

FF758D5FAE69456B90FB0291028C8273.description:
Differences on moral questions: e.g.,
abortion, divorce, and remarriage.

C15D10C9A8794C69A0FDE968E4FFC374.description:
Differences in sacramental economy
and practice, particularly the lack of
the Sacrament of Holy Orders and,
consequently, of a valid Eucharist.

DF6822717071463D905C23999B1DC729.description:
Differences in doctrine, e.g., Calvinist
belief in predestination.

91661962AA0B4430915DEE1A397FA38C.description:
Differences in acceptance of the authority
of the pope.

DEA50BFC9C0749AAA1DF0A15CAA9CD49.description:
Some common liturgical practices, e.g.,
common cycle of Scripture readings.

CA20F1FA7BB54CE1ACE24CA9342DE8FA.description:
In many cases, common moral
convictions.

F769EF2019D5481D8ACB23A1969438C3.description:
Baptisms celebrated with the Trinitarian
formula and proper intention are
considered valid by the Catholic Church.

959EF44188414868A7ED64201879BE43.description:
Common beliefs about Christ derived
from Scripture.

F6BEF132825849BBB24C88CB7360402C.description:
Common ties between the Catholic Church
and these ecclesial communions.

A58CB346F12C4180A6CBF65D213B656E.description:
Who founded these various ecclesial
communities and why?

3B1A934C11314071A987B2F5F3633433.description:
Ecclesial communions: Anglican (Episcopalian),
Lutheran, Reformed Christian.

911F7CDA7094468790935A8186C3FA90.description:
Ecumenical councils: not all accepted by
the Orthodox Churches.

B5DFBBF6B23E4678ABA484AA0D92C8E6.description:
Some Marian dogmas are taught in a
different way.

D25B6AAC90534F29A3B7208D19D14FE6.description:
Differences in sacramental law and
practice (e.g., Orthodox tolerate divorce
and remarriage).

782D91B8F8904960A43DEF14226D5F57.description:
A few doctrinal formulations in the
liturgy: the Eastern Orthodox Churches
use the original wording of the Nicene
Creed and do not accept the addition of
the filioque (the Holy Spirit proceeds from
the Father and the Son).

3551DDEEB02F41E4B32D51384D398495.description:
Most significant: Orthodox Churches
do not recognize the infallibility or the
primacy of jurisdiction of the Pope.

57A60754252848E9A9270D1B2C362FE3.description:
Differences between the Catholic Church and
Eastern Orthodox Churches.

9C701686BA954B4785A054B209A924B6.description:
Same core doctrine, beliefs, and moral
teachings.

33EBF4E8F21B439FBC51479498DF1CE8.description:
Orthodox Churches and Catholic Church
have strong ties to each other.

DE5F8735CC9F4C1FB6CE2C0A241C2170.description:
They share the same liturgy but not the
same bonds of episcopal communion.

DE90A823A0E54581BEBFFC89441D9A35.description:
Difference between Orthodox Churches and
Eastern Catholic Churches.

0CB2CD0997AA4075851FADDC997ABEEB.description:
Different forms of Church governance
emerged.
a) Eastern Churches were governed by
synods with a patriarch.
b) Latin Church was monarchical with
the pope as final authority.

3C3B12DD676E44328703FAFF5246B3B2.description:
Growing cultural and political differences
between East and West.

7899BFBC3A2240A9BCB80CA6D80DD5F6.description: Contributing causes to the Schism of 1054.

4CA96914CEE44BC994D2D04F8C94CB64.description: The Schism of 1054 resulted in the establishment of the Eastern Orthodox Churches.

0A0ECE10939242F79FF1630DCB11D767.description:
The Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox
Church were one until 1054.

B875D0D5AC074F7091B4815643009EF7.description:
Modern dialogue with the Oriental
Orthodox Catholics has made progress in
healing this schism.

538F5D3238854B40951A91241238E23B.description:
Those who believed the Monophysite
heresy (that Jesus did not have both a
divine nature and a human nature) also
broke away from full communion with the
Church and formed what are called the
Oriental Orthodox Churches.

4A96C5843F0F462587A5BBE0A09035F8.description: Following the Council of Chalcedon in 451.

4FF5DDB0A0064D9EB3A0641EB5D2C3E2.description:
Modern dialogue with those who did
not return has made progress in healing
this schism.

5C2B81E68A55430AA1E042014EF332A5.description: Later some returned to union with Rome.

106326D5538849CE94C0A0B3B0C43FDF.description:
Because of a dispute over the title of Mary
as Mother of God, some Churches, such as
the Assyrian Church, broke away from
full communion.

B185A2CE22A644339A228466B019AD61.description: Following the Council of Ephesus in 431.

E8572F1EDE894DC384ED6F21A9CC6FC5.description:
From the very beginning of the Church, there have
been rifts and serious dissension (CCC, no. 817).
Serious dissensions resulted in breaks from full
communion with the Church.

8BDAD71F80B94898AC3CB18E2811199D.description:
All the baptized, including those in imperfect
communion with the Catholic Church, are
members of Christ’s Body, have the right to be
called Christian, and are brothers and sisters to
members of the Catholic Church (UR, no. 3).

0B26CEA33DBA499284CFE390F32B2E23.description:
The ecumenical movement works to overcome
obstacles to full communion.

19C25783BDBB4D5DAE1027A2748CA3D5.description:
Christian ecclesial communities do not have a
validly ordained priesthood or the Eucharist.

F2D7B5EAEB984539B8B313368A262E6A.description:
Christian churches (Orthodox Churches) are
those with a validly ordained priesthood and
the Eucharist (CCC, nos. 838).

9EE2FA5BD0CD46A0AFB1ED67B5E65891.description:
The communion is imperfect because of
differences in doctrine, discipline, and/or
ecclesiastical structure.

0C97EF13477843C3917430788E07BDC2.description:
Members of other Christian churches and ecclesial
communities are in imperfect communion with the
Catholic Church (CCC, nos. 836-838).

4B3543B3DD584C18916F0BE9765BAA0D.description:
Baptized people are in full communion with the
Catholic Church when they are joined with Christ
in the visible structure of the Church through the
profession of faith, the reception of the sacraments,
and respect and obedience toward those in
authority in the Church (CIC, c. 205).

A6D22F37FA814BDC8F91CD71A47AE2DB.description:
Christian Churches and Ecclesial
Communities Apart from the
Catholic Church

15DF1B3D3C444DDCB9FE9A7343857962.description:
The Catholic Church, in and through the pope
and the bishops, is entrusted with protecting the
50
Doctrinal Elements of a Curriculum Framework for the
Development of Catechetical Materials for Young People of High School Age
whole Deposit of Faith, that is, the Revelation
preserved in Scripture and in Tradition (CCC, nos.
84,
863-865, 1202).

04AB47DC10CD47AF8D804306F6E5B85A.description:
This role of ensuring an authentic proclamation
of God’s Revelation has been handed down in an
unbroken line to the Apostles’ successors—the
pope and bishops (CCC, nos. 861-862).

FFF67CD78DDE4B209D46834D2E1A37D0.description:
The Apostles were entrusted with faithfully
proclaiming the Gospel and spreading the Good
News Jesus Christ had entrusted to them (CCC,
no. 858).

89BF7A51F44F4DFAB59C86225445309D.description:
Jesus Christ instituted the Church on the
foundation of the Apostles (CCC, nos. 857-860).

DC362E1C265B4A0A87968D5E137F7001.description: The Catholic Church and Divine Revelation.

42CD52F324E04ACCBF7F98C2C2084545.description:
The Church is the Body of Christ; he is our Head,
we are the members of the Body (CCC, nos.
790-795).

AD0644F680224DD0BC6FC313BA35E244.description:
Guided, sustained, and sanctified by the Father
through the Son and Holy Spirit (CCC, nos.
767-768).

11DE81C6505C45E3901CD9D0CCB3ECE2.description: Revealed by the Holy Spirit (CCC, nos. 767-768).

2A3FB49FD61A4411A51AA7CE8A08F880.description:
Divinely instituted by Jesus Christ, the Son of God
and the Second Person of the Trinity (CCC, nos.
763-766).

BA6C699D4C88450EB284C286A3F864E3.description:
Pre-figured in the People of Israel (CCC, nos.
761-762).

671579DC4597484F891FBB6E489F16B8.description:
Planned by God the Father from the beginning of
time (CCC, no. 759).

6D617AD3956140F0AE1BBD41B0D1AF69.description:
Divine foundation of the Catholic Church (CCC, nos.
758-769).

C27ED64FD6C243329CF47624057CED00.description:
Divine Revelation ends with the death of the
last Apostle (CCC, nos. 66-67).

DF5EC6BCFE1C4D8B9DF9A8ACAB387FB0.description:
Sends the Holy Spirit upon the Apostles
at Pentecost.

158DA7727AB044EF8A789AB8910B24BB.description:
Promises to send the Paraclete, the
Holy Spirit.

D72B8916274D45DDB44D1D98F6D6A1C1.description:
Identifies himself as God’s Son and
addresses God as Father.

D787DDFF780946D0AA0C302EF88CCA0A.description:
Jesus reveals the Trinity, the central mystery of
faith (CCC, nos. 648-650).

87CE8D5B17BC4185B7A84B634F1CA28D.description:
Jesus’ own proclamation of his divine
Sonship (CCC, no. 590).

9D4BADA4F92044D9B77EA14706C69DF9.description:
St. Peter’s confession of faith at Caesarea
Philippi (CCC, no. 552).

E8E93933CBAD4DA78612A1FBF4FBF478.description:
Jesus’ Baptism by St. John the Baptist
(CCC, nos. 535-537).

F8B72AFDFA804D97B37977238B3DF122.description:
Jesus is revealed as the Son of God and
the Christ or “Anointed One” of God, the
Messiah foretold by God through the prophets
of Israel.

E5D2175C07BC4F22BEB29A43B1E6B65E.description:
In Jesus, the Eternal Word made man, is found
the fullness of Revelation.

F6D58529FC7F4BA1B3C8819501DBB9C5.description:
Divine Revelation in the New Testament (CCC,
nos. 65-67, 124-127, 151, 422-455).

067AB02B80CD45549CC7A5BA1442CDE2.description:
He gives the Israelites a code of both
worship and morality.

CF8D2550B6D94B59956FB314FD00F5B0.description:
He tells Moses about himself: “I am who
am” (Ex 3:14).

3357823865A04A6AA8589F02E861D332.description:
God reveals himself to Moses and forms the
People of Israel (CCC, nos. 62-64).

BCDE114727D341C987F0792DBC8AF16B.description: “Israel” was the name given Jacob by God.

DBA5543E831949E8A44D34D75561F892.description:
Abraham’s grandson, Jacob, has twelve
sons whose descendants shape the twelve
tribes of the People of Israel.

6BB79FAF8B9343A89388BD7D0EAE8AFE.description:
In and through Abraham’s descendants, he
forms the People of Israel:

422E5273A143472CB671DACC633C5B9F.description:
God reveals himself to Abraham: the
beginning of a people of faith (CCC, nos. 72,
992, 2571).

0C315252700A4166882C3B6166790193.description:
The Triune God is revealed in the work of
Creation, which originates with the Father
and is brought into being through the Word
(Jesus Christ) by the power of the Holy Spirit
(CCC, nos. 282, 314).

1584832472924B8BB76FB38AD3B1AE60.description: Divine Revelation in the Old Testament times.

F67D896C1CF942CA84AB55DCD2BE5912.description:
Tracing Divine Revelation through the history
of salvation.
